The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as, including but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period required by any agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
The Bookstores have the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Online Textbook Orders from FY 2006-2007
Accounts Payable Records from FY 1996-1997
Sales Records from CY 2002
Month-End Reports from FY 2006-2007

ACTION ITEMS 
Contracts (The attached individual Master Agreements are included in an abbreviated format.  Please refer to the attached Master Agreement template for the full text.)
Lionakis – Master Agreement and Project Assignment Amendment for Design Professional Services
In January, 2012 the District issued a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Professional Design Services for projects related to the updated Facilities Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College.  Outreach efforts included posting to the Purchasing page on the District website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to 12 minority and woman-owned small disadvantaged businesses.
	 
On February 21, 2012, in response to the RFQ the District received Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) from twenty-one (21) firms.  A District Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District and Evergreen Valley College reviewed each SOQ.  The panel members consisted of staff from District Purchasing, two EVC Division Deans and the EVC Vice President, Administrative Services.  The Panel discussed the SOQ’s received and ranked the firms.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected five (5) firms to be invited for presentation/interview for the West Campus / Automotive Technology project (in alphabetical order):
	 
            Aedis / Carrier Johnson (SBE)
            BCA
            Kwan Henmi 
            Lionakis
            tBP Architecture
	 
The interviews were held on March 16, 2012.  The interview panel consisted of staff from the Automotive Technology program, a Division Dean, the EVC Vice President, Administrative Services and a District representative.  Gilbane facilitated, but did not vote on the selection.  Based on the compilation of SOQ and interviews, the interview panel selected Lionakis as the Design Professional for this project.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a Master Agreement and Addendum #1 for Design Professional Services and Project Assignment Amendment (PAA), including programming of the West Campus and full design services for the Automotive Technology project, with the selected firm Lionakis.
Dougherty & Dougherty – Master Agreement for Design Professional Services
In concert with the process and interview described above in item 1a, it was the intent to issue a Master Agreement for as-yet unidentified project(s) to a firm deemed most qualified by the Interview Panel. (Again, the panel members consisted of a representative of the District, two EVC Division Deans and the EVC Vice President, Administrative Services.)  The Panel selected the firm of Dougherty & Dougherty to receive the at-large Master Agreement.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a Master Agreement for Design Professional Services with Dougherty & Dougherty.
Allana Buick & Bers – Master Agreement and Project Assignment Amendment for Design Professional Services
The Gullo Student Center building has been leaking for some time.  Preliminary investigation has indicated the need to replace the entire roof system.  As part of the Scheduled Maintenance project at EVC, a project to repair/renovate the roof of the Gullo Student Center was developed.   Due to the urgency to repair this roof prior to the next wet season, proposals for design professional services were sought from three firms: 
	 
Allana Buick & Bers  (WBE)
Mike Citta  (SBE)
Simpson Gumpertz Hager
	 
Proposals were received April 5, 2012.  (Mike Citta did not submit due to the breadth of services required.)  The proposals were reviewed by a representative of the District and the EVC Vice President, Administrative Services. Based on the proposals received, Allana Buick & Bers was determined to be the most qualified for this work.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a Master Agreement for Design Professional Services, and a Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) for the Gullo Student Center Roof Replacement project with Allana Buick & Bers.
CSW/Stuber-Stroeh Engineering Group Inc. - Project Assignment Amendment for Design Professional Services
There is no consolidated and comprehensive information identifying the major utility systems for Evergreen Valley College. Some sections of the campus have no information available on any utilities.  As part of the Campus Site Improvements project for EVC, a Utility Mapping project has been established.
	 
Following on the March 13, 2012 approval by the Board of Trustees of master agreements for civil engineering services, Requests for Proposal were sent to the four firms with those agreements to solicit specific proposals related to The Utility Mapping of the Evergreen Valley College campus.  Proposals were received April 16, 2012 and reviewed by a representative of the District and the EVC Vice President, Administrative Services.  Based on the proposals received, CSW/Stuber-Stroeh Engineering Group Inc. was determined to be the most qualified for this work.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) to the existing Master Agreement for Design Professional Services with CSW/Stuber-Stroeh Engineering Group Inc. for Utility Mapping of the EVC campus.

items.item_details:
To comply with Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statement 43 and 45, the San Jose Evergreen Community College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the  delivery and funding of 100% of medical, prescription drug, and EAP benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.  In addition Faculty and MSC employees receive 100% of subsidized medical, prescription drug, and EAP benefits until s/he attains age 65 ("Bridge Benefits").  The long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was determined to be $95,087,707 per an actuarial study issued by Rael and Letson dated June 30, 2007.  Taxable Other Post Employment Benefit (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009, in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and were deposited into the OPEB Trust.  An updated actuarial study by Rael & Letson dated June 30, 2011, determined that the long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments is $40,376,440 with net assets of $49,703,700, which means that the liability is over-funded as of June 30, 2011, by $9,327,260.
	 
Issuing the OPEB bonds ensured that the District was compliant with GASB Statements 43 and 45, allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time, and provided the District with short-term General Fund savings.  The District initially incorporated capitalized interest which provided the District two years without any OPEB-related debt service payments from the General Fund.  
	 
On March 13, 2012, the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution 031312-2 authorizing the re-marketing of the bonds to further reduce the exposure to the General Fund and to lock in a fixed rate for the next 15 years.  It is estimated that in FY 2012-2013, the General Fund will contribute $808,705 towards the $2.49 million debt-service obligation and $1.95 million in FY 2013-2014 and FY 2014-2015, which remains less than the annual cost of benefits of approximately $3.4 million.
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88%.  Attached for reference are 1) the updated actuarial report dated June 30, 2011; 2) the investment portfolio as of March 31, 2012, illustrating assets of $47.65 million; 3) the performance letter dated April 13, 2012, from Benefit Trust; and 4) the presentation from the RBOA.

On January 24, the Board received the first update using the "Workplan Dashboard" to provide a quick "at-a-glance" review.  At this same meeting it was agreed the Board's Committee on Self Evaluation; namely, Trustees Cruz, Okamura and Lease, should remain in place in order to a) provide monthly "dashboard" updates; and b) restart the annual board self evaluation review cycle.  Trustee Okamura accepted responsibility for providing the monthly dashboard updates.

The Student Success Constituents Workgroup met for the second time on April 30, 2012.  The notes from the March 27 meeting and the agenda for the April 30 meeting are attached below.  The group continues on task and on track in the development of implementation strategies designed to address the Board's policy on Student Success.   Highlights of the work underway include:
	 
1.  Continuing to refine the draft definition of Student Success that is representative of the mission of our District and the goals and objectives of our students.
2.  Developing a set of quantitative and qualitative metrics to measure institutional progress toward student success.
3.  Scheduling a series of focus group sessions with students to elicit their own definition of student success.
4.  Developing an advocacy strategy to monitor proposed related legislation, regulatory changes and other mandates to ensure that the position established by the Board of Trustees and District Constituents is reflected as appropriate.
5.  Developing a timeline for specific deliverables that is and long term.
	 
 The next meeting of the Student Success Constituent Workgroup was set for May 14, 2012.  It is expected that the SJECCD draft definition of Student Success will be further refined and that the group will review proposed metrics to be provided by the Director of the Office of Institutional Effectiveness and Research.  In addition, the group will continue discussion on a set of short and long range strategies designed to support student success that are both short and long range in nature.  In particular, the group will identify current efforts already underway that need to be evaluated and strengthened to ensure continuity.
